replies.text: @quesoqueso7598 You‚Äôre right, older folks view him as way too vulgar and not of Christian values, which I can‚Äôt blame them if you listen to his music. But those older folks know of Boosie and agree with his homophobia. Grooming girls to be lesbians kissing in somebody‚Äôs backseat can be forgiving as someone on the panel said about lesbians that we all know but nobody has an issue with. The don‚Äôt see Boosie in the same demonic darkness that they view the black gays who have supported his career. I think it‚Äôs safe to say he is a self hating DL black man and it‚Äôs unfortunate because he could live in his truth and be a beacon of hope for other gay/bi rappers. Instead he decided a long time ago to hate himself and has instead decided to double down.

replies.author: @quesoqueso7598
replies.text: @G-Rated Older folks may not view him as a full on christian, but to them the "worst" sin is being gay. Those types of "christians" excuse themselves from other sins cause it's more forgivable than being gay. Him being homophobic is enough for "God to be working on him". While there are many self hating DL black men, I don't think Boosie is one of them (despite his name lol and lack of evidence to support that.) It is contradicting that he rejects his lesbian daughter and walked out on the color purple with his other daughters for showing lesbianism,  yet talks about it in his songs. Yet, I expect men to contradict themselves. Especially hetero men. Liking lesbians for s3xual gratification vs real life  is something a hetero man would do.

author: @UndertheNeedle282
text: I'm so glad that about how I was raised. Both of my daughters told me they were queer. I gave them both the space to explore. One decided she was actually straight and the other decided she was queer. I love them both and their sexual identity has no impact on my love and acceptance of them. Give your children the space to be who they are, as long as they are good and kind human beings.

author: @im_tiffany
text:
My thing about the "kids  are impressionable" thing is, yes, we know! Why do you think so many queer people tried being 'straight' before they felt comfortable enough coming out. 
Like there are worse things for kids to be under the impression of. 
So what if a kid thinks they're gay for a minute? They have the right to explore their gender and sexuality at their own pace. 
We should be more open to how fluid this stuff is and quit trying to force these hateful rigid standards. 
These standards need to die!!!

replies.author: @im_tiffany
replies.text:
@ruppelspoopels¬† Ok, I understand your point, and I don't disagree with it. What i'm confused about is why did you gender the point of my comment? 

My take is clearly about how people who use the excuse of protecting the children against the "gay agenda" are dumb and that children should have the right to explore their identities freely. 

I understand that this discussion is clearly black, but why are you singling out black women and dl men under my comment in particular? 

If black women stopped their homophobia will dl men finally feel safe enough to come out? 

Is it on black women alone to stop upholding the system of patriarchy, or is it a system that everybody upholds in one way or another and we can all benefit from destroying it?

I mean call em out when you see it, but I'm trying to understand what the ACTUAL point was of responding to my gender neutral comment with gender was?

replies.author: @breannaflores4175
replies.text:
I remember questioning my sexuality around 7-8 years old because my mom unknowingly put on D.E.B.S thinking it was basically a live-action Totally Spies (spoiler it‚Äôs about horny lesbians). I told my older cousins about the movie after and they IMMEDIATELY started pressuring me to claim a label of bi/ lesbian/ hetero when I was sitting there like ‚ÄúI saw this movie recently‚Äù. I knew gay people existed but was too young to see the horny side of ANYONE so I was very confused and scared for a couple years. Scared because I didn‚Äôt hate the movie and was raised in a family of ‚Äúyou can be gay, just not in front of me‚Äù so I was trying to figure out ‚Äúdoes not hating this automatically make me part of it‚Äù when I was barely out of toddlerhood.

I went from watching a new movie to being asked my sexuality in a matter of minutes and days, and no one thought it was weird.

author: @kenyasmith2652
text:
28:04

In 1987, a 4 year old boy named Lattie McGee was brutally tortured to death by his mother‚Äôs boyfriend. Lattie suffered severe injuries such as burns, lacerations, and a broken collarbone, and he was severely malnourished. The boyfriend explained that he was ‚Äúdisciplining‚Äù Lattie because he believed that the little boy was showing gay tendencies. This was an excerpt from Lattie‚Äôs Find A Grave page:

‚ÄúTo muffle the innocent boy's cries, the couple would sometimes stuff a rag in his mouth.

Campbell did not like the 4-year-olds "effeminate" voice so to toughen the young boy he would starve him then beat him if he complained. On the hot August night, Campbell and Alicia stuffed a rag into Lettie's mouth, potato peels were placed on his eyes, his hands were bound, and he was hung by his feet in the closet. His complaints of having problems swallowing and that he was in pain from the broken collarbone and broken pelvis, were ignored.‚Äù

Both the mother and the boyfriend are serving time right now for this boy‚Äôs death. Life without parole.

replies.author: @BlaQueerFlow
replies.text: Thank you for this.

replies.author: @kenyasmith2652
replies.text: @BlaQueerFlow You‚Äôre welcome. I first learned about this story from The Steve Wilkos Show where he actually visited the prison that Lattie‚Äôs mother was serving time in and interviewed her. The episode is called Jailed for Life, and I think I was in the 8th or 9th grade when it aired. During that episode, the monster of a mom showed little to no remorse for what happened to her son. Lattie had a brother who was also tortured by the boyfriend, but thankfully he survived.

replies.author: @kenyasmith2652
replies.text: @smoothsavage2870 Absolutely. It‚Äôs definitely sickening to watch.

author: @lamenia
text:
20:00
 A child being exposed to diverse identities will allow them to be more tolerant. Exposure does not affect a person's identity.

replies.author: @Osyrus707
replies.text: Two things can be true, and exposure can affect a person's outlook and identity. Especially impressionable children.

replies.author: @tari8134
replies.text: @Osyrus707 I like how people assume this with nothing to back it up except their opinion.

replies.author: @Happilydprssd2.0
replies.text: @Osyrus707 no. Exposure will allow them to question and explore who they are. Exposure doesn‚Äôt change someone‚Äôs sexual orientation if that was true 99% of queer folk would be straight.

replies.author: @TheeAntisocialXxtrovert
replies.text: Tolerance isn't a good thing though. It's different from actually accepting someone.

author: @SketchytheChangeling
text:
27:45 This double standard is something I (black, m, cishet) had to combat in real time recently. Was having a conversation with an older woman at work, we'll call her Tanya (black, f, cishet) about how social media conditions people to feel entitled to know about the personal lives of the people they follow, and when a public figure decides to be more private about what they share online, the automatic assumption is "oh they must have something to hide" when the reality can be as simple as "I don't feel like sharing this anymore."

Tanya and I were on the same page about how this is messed up and we should reevaluate how we interact with people online, but all that suddenly went out the window when she brought up a classmate of hers that came out as a trans woman. At one point this classmate had been journaling her transition online, and suddenly stopped, and Tanya is suddenly so inquisitive about why that's the case and is assuming her classmate is trying to hide her trans identity from people, literal MINUTES after we just had a conversation about feeling entitled to people's info online and how we can't just assume malicious intent when people decide to be more private. Never mind the fact that we live in the Caribbean (which is, as Olay said, CRIPPLINGLY homophobic) and that would be the most likely reason why Tanya's classmate stopped posting. I pointed this contradiction out to Tanya, only for her to insist that it's different for reasons that she somehow cannot articulate. Shocker.

It's an incredibly frustrating thing to deal with and I can only imagine what it's like for LGBT people who have to deal with these contradictory people on the daily.

author: @mercyb8955
text: Olay, I would love it if you did a panel of black and disabled people.

replies.author: @deangelamullins1897
replies.text: @mercyb8955 omg yesssssss

replies.author: @juratory8876
replies.text: Yes! As an AuDHD Black woman, I would love to see this happen! When people talk about disability and neurodivergent rights, it's usually in the vein of what white disabled and neurodivergent people experience and focuses specifically on accommodations/justice for them. Rarely are Black and POC disabled/neurodivergent people given the opportunity to talk about our experiences navigating the intersections of racism and ableism on a structural and interpersonal level.

replies.author: @mercyb8955
replies.text: @juratory8876 That's so true! I would love to see Imani Barbarin back on the platform.

author: @greennubula
text:
i think it is also SUPERRR important to point out that the lgbtqia+ community is not solely about being not straight, it is also encompassing of not being allosexual. The asexual community encompasses straight people as well, that simply are not allosexual. i think it is VERY needed that you have an asexual person (especially black aces, bc of how hypersexualized black people & bodies are conditioned/portrayed/etc.) on ur episodes, Olay, especially when discussing the lgbtqia+ community. bc it is really important to talk about & include the ace community bc we are all conditioned to buy into & be allosexual, straight, & cis. allosexuality is not discussed enough, in these conversations. as well as the reality of romanticism, & how for a lot of people their sexuality is not tied to their romanticism, and for a lot of people they are tied together. bc there are plenty of people who are (for example) ace & aro, ace & panromantic, or even bisexual & homoromantic. i think as a community & people not discussing & distinguishing these things causes a lot of people to not like/not know what labels to choose. like there is a large portion of queerness & straightness, that we simply do NOT talk about, bc the existence of & what asexuality & romanticism are, is simply NOT talked about the majority of the time when lgbtqia+ conversations are had. & i truly believe that more people would identify as either one or both a lot more if people had the language & knowledge to ascribe to their experience, feelings, & reality when it comes to sexuality, romanticism, etc. 
so Olay, PLZZ have aces & aros on ur show, we as an aspec community would really appreciate it. thank u sm for ur videos :)

author: @HummingFeather
text:
Marquise talking about being accountable to change is real. My intersectional identities of being queer, nonbinary, Black and Brown, and disabled because of having autism, I face an onslaught of violence from the very people that say they are fighting for people like me. I have recently been disowned. Change is a tough thing when parents, people, and community are not open to seeing the judge in themselves. Constantly hiding myself has done nothing but get me neglected. People just want to shut up and it is killing me. I am happy to fight to be seen. I am not gonna survive if my grandmother and father refuse to accept me. 
Also thank you! Speak on that femmephobia is a big thing. That is why I am happy to lose a fight if it means people stop playing with us.

author: @jessicaflemister4825
text:
The topic at the end is something I‚Äôve been thinking about for a while so I‚Äôm soo glad bye gave the resources on this! I‚Äôm ADHD but didn‚Äôt find out until last year @ 37‚Ä¶my environment want the worst but we were definitely spanked, and I was more than my siblings. Not sure that things would‚Äôve been different if we knew I was adhd but I know it‚Äôs affected my mental health so much and I wanna make sure NOT to repeat this with my daughter. She‚Äôs only 4 but on the spectrum and I make a conscious effort not to repeat this cycle, but I definitely wanna read more on this connection to slavery and parenting with LOVE over care!

Great episode Olay!

author: @DanielleGillespie
text:
This is such a good conversation! 
4 years ago my oldest attempted suicide. Going thru the process of seeing different providers, I noticed the professionals were using the pronouns They/Them. 
I am progressive. But also a Black mom! I had to get to the bottom of it! Especially since the drs couldn't tell me anything bc of their age. 
I flat out them if they were non-binary or trans! (Found out later that's not a good idea) They came out! Then I came out as Bi. ALL my school yard relationships were with females until I was scared to death at church! Grew up in a fundamentalist Pentecostal church. 
Funny my parents have 3 kids and none of them are straight! 
When going thru the process of transitioning and all the drs appts they needed consent from me and dad. At 1st we thought it was weird AF that the staff kept praising us for excepting them. It was never a second thought! Then I realized Oh...bc so many parents disown their kids, especially Black parents! So sad!

replies.author: @DanielleGillespie
replies.text: Also, I didn't understand everything about being non-binary or trans. But the drs gave me resources and plus I looked up information!

This is what pride feels like listening to you beautiful young folks.
Thank you!ü´∂üèΩü•≤

author: @Belial289
text: i think there should be a shift in language to say romantic orientation instead of sexual, just keeping in line with the fact that being queer isn't inherently about sex. no orientation is inherently about sex and what's in someone's pants isn't immediately obvious, nor should that matter for the laaaaaaaarge majority of strangers a person meets. it's also so incredibly INCREDIBLYYY strange for parents to ask their gay sons if they're a top or bottom. imagine immediately sexualizing your child just to affirm that they're masculine in your eyes. so gross. besides, bottoms work harder than the president.

replies.author: @BlaQueerFlow
replies.text: It‚Äôs difficult because not all queer people are romantic or desire romance.

replies.author: @Belial289
replies.text: @BlaQueerFlow that is true too, yes.

replies.author: @Joe.grizzly
replies.text:
@Belial289 well the root word Sex, in this instance, refers to biological sex(Male/Female) not sexual intercourse‚Ä¶.people just assume bc they see the word Sex and forget there‚Äôs a such thing as homographs üò≠ and plus it being about Sex(ual activity) fits their agenda and bias that gays are ‚Äúhypersexual‚Äù or exist due to sexual trauma, etc‚Ä¶

So yea with that said, I tend to agree with you when it comes to word choices like these. It‚Äôs confusing to them and most are too unwilling to learn and educate themselves and others.

replies.author: @moomin2833
replies.text: i agree that the right overly focuses on the sexual aspects of our community but sex is and has always been an integral part to both our oppression and liberation! would removing sex from public expressions of our desires make bigots more comfortable around us? maybe. and yes the statement "queerness is not all about sex" is absolutely true and worth emphasizing. i just dont feel that gaining rights & understanding based on a conditional acceptance of who we are is really worth it imo. if people can only stomach us when we self-sanitize, they were never going to care in a way that really matters anyway.

text: This was such as a great episode.  I have looked up and aqcuired the resources reference during this conversation.  I am a mom of a black boy adn I am always thinking of what i can do to keep him safe and preserve his life , even at the risk of impinging on his freedom ( to feel fully, to question authority and to even rough house with is friends on the play ground).  While i don't beat him, I am punative and will dliver discipline swiftly, because " I don't want the police to kill him".  This conversation has mke me rethink the way I discpline my son and I am looking  forward to diving into the learning about (more compasisonate) parenting to have my kid thirive instead of survive- although I hoping to find a happy medium.  Thank you!

text: Lets be real, we see all kinds of "straight" men on gay apps and have forever. The dudes with wives and girlfriends that no one would ever suspect. Even if they will never admit it to anyone in their life, they're still acting on it and have this attraction or willingness to experiment. Boosie absolutely has had gay thoughts, LOTS of men have. A much larger chunk than people realize.

replies.author: @butterfish-g9f
replies.text: Oh yeah, and a lot of them are outright predators about it because they won't treat the people they fetishize as full human beings. I can't tell you how many stories I've heard or experienced myself of straight men lusting for gay or trans people on the side as a casual thing. Especially hyper conservative men. The most dangerous attraction because they won't hesitate to ruin your life if people find out about them preying on you.

author: @lashelleullie
text: Hiding was a behavior passed down through generations as a way to stay safe and protected. I think about plantation mothers who tried to shield their children from harm. My grandmother raised me with that same instinct; I believe she wanted to protect my queerness and also avoid reflecting any aspects of her own parenting that she might have been uncomfortable with. I understand these actions come from a place of love and a desire for safety.

author: @glenny4justice
text: Idk if this is the case with Boosie but I've noticed a lot of black people, mainly men, stating that their dislike for gays came from bad experiences from bad actors in the community. While the very valid argument could be made thay they wanted to feel that way in the first place, you have to know that alot of these men didn't have LGBT positive spaced when they were growing up so the ignorance and one trackness just grows into adulthood unfortunately

author: @toddstevens9248
text:
I‚Äôm a 46 year old, gay White cisman who was fem presenting as a child. I grew up in a politically moderate  small city in Washington State during the 80‚Äôs and 90‚Äôs. I moved at 18 to a conservative County in California, and in my late 20‚Äôs moved to a liberal city in California. 

I‚Äôve traveled to large and small cities throughout the US from the MidWest to the South East to the Northeast and everything in between and I would love to see the studies you‚Äôre referencing when characterizing the Black Community as the least homophobic minority group in the US. That has not been my experience. 

The most overt, frequent, unsafe verbal and yes, physical attacks I‚Äôve experienced because of my sexual orientation came from cis-presenting, straight-presenting Black men and when speaking about this in safe spaces with other gay/bi men of every race, I have found my reality is not just my own. 

For this reason, I‚Äôd ask you to reconsider this assumption or  provide research/data to support it. Maybe I missed it, but when doing my own searching, I did not find any peer-reviewed study that bares this to be true. I think it‚Äôs important to be accurate when making generalizations about an entire group of people.

text: Think of ypur hierarchy of needs. At the base ypu have physiological needs. Which includes sex. Just above that is safety and security. If one does not have that strong foundation things like self esteem, self actualization, and confidence are hindered.

author: @Jewel_Dropper
text: Before this goes live I'm putting my two cents out there right now: imho Boosie is the litmus test for separating the art from the artists. Boosie makes good music & has horrible opinions (as do most rappers). I'm also kinda tired of us having to stop listening to black artists cause they are also shitty people and so we gotta collectively shun them while "not being a monolith", when the fact is most entertainers are shitty people and their works are still allowed to be enjoyed the masses cause said people are usually white and not rappers. I'm not saying lets break out the R. Kelly (gotta draw the line somewhere), but are we really better off as a people without "Wipe Me Down"? I think not.

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: I can‚Äôt see how Wipe me down, a single 15 year old song (that is a remix to another rapper‚Äôs song) requires us to hold tight to a man who pays adults to rape his underage son, and ostracizes his daughter with violent homophobia. Boosie‚Äôs contribution to both hip hop and the Black community have been negligible. Moreover, we can critique artists without it meaning you‚Äôre being forced to boycott their music‚Ä¶ which in any event, I‚Äôd like to reiterate, is only 1 song in the case of Boosie. Also, its not about separating the art from the artist, its about the fact that many in the community don‚Äôt think there needs to be a separation because they don‚Äôt disapprove of his homophobia and toxic ideas of masculinity that causes him to harm his own children and preach that harm‚Äîthat‚Äôs the problem and that‚Äôs the subject of this discussion‚Äîwhy the community holds onto boosie and how much of that is because the community doesn‚Äôt disagree with boosie

replies.author: @Jewel_Dropper
replies.text: @olurinatti ¬†so the "wipe me down" part was a joke and I agree his contribution to hip-hop and the community have been negligible hence me picking a song thats so old and why but I dont really think anyone is holding onto Boosie; especially the black community.  Boosie only makes headlines these days for saying ignorant shit & regularly appearing on Vlad, but nobody is ever talking about his music, I mean he dropped 5 albums this year alone. & I'm glad to hear this will be a discussion about critiquing and not trying to force folks to boycott; the title like just gave me boycott vibes.

replies.author: @Jewel_Dropper
replies.text: End of the say I'm not gonna die on the hill of defending Boosie, but I'm also not putting too much thought into what he says & I feel like the general public is. I'm not tuning into Boosies personal life or LGBT takes like I'm not tuning into Too Short for woman's rights issues or Young Dolph for staying drug free.

author: @kareemabdulwahhab6919
text: My thing is, why cant I just be against a certain sexual proclivity? Anybody reads this comment, is going to acknowledge that they don‚Äôt accept every single sexual proclivity that people practice. So off of that, why can‚Äôt I?

replies.author: @BlaQueerFlow
replies.text: love is not a proclivity. maybe fisting, but not love and not people.

replies.author: @Tyra18.
replies.text: If being gay is sexual proclivity that someone can dislike, then same should be said about heterosexuality. Also why do care you about someone‚Äôs ‚Äúsexual proclivities‚Äù? Especially enough to publicly express disdain for them? You could keep it to yourself.

replies.author: @entertheomniverse727
replies.text: @Tyra18. I like to play devil's advocate so hear me out nobody's above calling out what they don't like or feeling uncomfortable about you got to understand that people for thousands of years were raised on Christian values and the old ways of living Adam and Eve not Adam and Steve and I'm not saying that to be hateful I'm saying that that's ingrained in people's minds that's how things should be God destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah no I wasn't just because of gay they completely lost themselves in sexual depravity but if you read Paul's story he was a gay man but him knowing that that's sinful he decided to be celibate we're going back to that one guy's point he can call out something that he doesn't want to participate in or associate with there's nothing wrong with that and if you want to say oh then I don't want to deal with somebody who's heterosexual go ahead but it sounds kind of silly when again it's been ingrained in everybody's culture for thousands of years not to say there's wasn't gay people back then I just mentioned Paul right but it's more accepted that it's the way it's supposed to be a man and a woman people can have an opinion you can too if you like but if you have so much pride why do you care about my opinion? I'm a humanitarian so regardless of how I look at other people's sexuality cuz I really don't give a fuck but I like the debating lol so I'm all for people not being killed because who they sleep with but "I'm not for you don't want to be my friend because I slept with this person you're evil or homophobic" because again in the Bible but also this is just how some people look at it that you can't accept behavior if you have differing values from it like for example I can't be friends with somebody who does crack or even drinks too much I don't even want to talk to somebody who does crack I'm not saying that it's correct but someone can look at being gay the same way that isn't for you to say that it's wrong you should just find the people that you are accepted from it's not that hard but again when it comes to people dying and being killed for their sexuality I completely understand the outrage but I also understand that everyone's entitled to their own opinion and lifestyle and you can surround yourself with people who support your lifestyle you don't have to surround yourself with people who don't and that goes for everybody the people I have around me like fully accept who they are I wouldn't have anybody around me that I felt some type of way about regardless of what the context is but anyway have a good day

replies.author: @kareemabdulwahhab6919
replies.text: @Tyra18.Same reason why you didn‚Äôt keep this opinion to yourself

replies.author: @kareemabdulwahhab6919
replies.text: @BlaQueerFlowLol sir that doesn‚Äôt make sense but I get it.

replies.author: @grandsome
replies.text:
Are you in bed with them, if no, how is their sexual proclivity any of you business. You don't go around chastising people who don't have the same favorite colour as you, why do your care about how people have sex if you're not participating?
(Assuming we're talking about consenting adults.)

author: @HummingFeather
text:
Marquise talking about being accountable to change is real. My intersectional identities of being queer, nonbinary, Black and Brown, and disabled because of having autism, I face an onslaught of violence from the very people that say they are fighting for people like me. I have recently been disowned. Change is a tough thing when parents, people, and community are not open to seeing the judge in themselves. Constantly hiding myself has done nothing but get me neglected. People just want to shut up and it is killing me. I am happy to fight to be seen. I am not gonna survive if my grandmother and father refuse to accept me. 
Also thank you! Speak on that femmephobia is a big thing. That is why I am happy to lose a fight if it means people stop playing with us.

author: @HummingFeather
text:
Marquise talking about being accountable to change is real. My intersectional identities of being queer, nonbinary, Black and Brown, and disabled because of having autism, I face an onslaught of violence from the very people that say they are fighting for people like me. I have recently been disowned. Change is a tough thing when parents, people, and community are not open to seeing the judge in themselves. Constantly hiding myself has done nothing but get me neglected. People just want to shut up and it is killing me. I am happy to fight to be seen. I am not gonna survive if my grandmother and father refuse to accept me. 
Also thank you! Speak on that femmephobia is a big thing. That is why I am happy to lose a fight if it means people stop playing with us.
